p: CFE in a serum-free medium is a functional assay used to investigate the survival of cells with stem-like properties [ 21]. Reducing the number of colony forming units is an important feature of potential chemotherapeutic compounds [ 22]. Treatment with the chloroform fraction of C. simensis at the IC 50 concentration (80 μg/mL) resulted in 100% prevention of colony formation of JIMT-1 cells. Treatment with solvent fractions of S. oxyacanthum (SO:2 and SO:3), C. simensis (CS:1 and CS:2) and V. leopoldi VL:1 and VL:2) significantly reduced CFE in a dose-dependent manner compared to the controls (Fig. 1b). In addition to reducing the number of colonies, treatment with the fractions in general resulted in smaller colonies than in control (Fig. 1c).
